div.p: tSettingPlaceType is an optional attribute attached to the element SETTINGPLACE in WRITINGTEXTUALFEATURES. It is modified by three values: fictive, real and identifiable. fictive signals imaginary settings or locations; real identifies those that are actual; identifiable applies in situations where the name of a location has been changed but is obviously modelled on a real place. For example, Margaret Laurence calls Neepawa, Manitoba, “Manawaka” in her novels, but we can identify it as Neepawa. tSettingClass is a sibling to tSettingPlaceType, which further describes the location of the fiction by specifying which ranks of society there are involved.

div.codeblock: <TSETTINGPLACE SETTINGPLACETYPE="real">Elizabeth Cary Falkland's play is set in Palestine, which was then a province of the Roman Empire.</TSETTINGSPLACE>
<TSETTINGPLACE SETTINGPLACETYPE="fictive">All of Willa Smyth's poems are set in an imaginary land called Sneed.</TSETTINGPLACE>
